comment_text:
The best way is to actually break down the conspiracy theory in reverse (starting with the motivation, ending with the end result) in order to show how illogical it is.

Lets look at the conspiracy theory that covid-19 was planned by the government(s) to control the populace: Let's start with what the government wants. Supposedly the government wants to control the populace.
- So why does the government want to control the populace?
- So that the people can be under their dominion? Why?
- How does this benefit them?
- Control is meant to give a person power. So why would need more power than they already have now? The amount of power they have now is pretty good.
- No other country would be ok with this.

Next, the government wants to control the populace by causing a coronavirus pandemic.
- Why would they use a disease to control the populace?
- Spreading a disease would cause great harm to themselves.
- Why would they use a more mild virus that is similar to the flu? People arent scared of the flu anymore.
- If they wanted to use a disease to control people, they could at least create a very dangerous one, like a contageous prion disease or a lethal virus similar to rabies or ebola. These would scare people into complying.

Once they create a pandemic, they use lockdowns, quarantines, mandate masks, and regulations to initiate their control.
- These things are not about controlling. They are putting a halt to things, which is dissapointing but not life threatening for the populace, and greatly harmful for themselves.
- These means to "control" the populace are not benefitting them, but are in fact harming them. They are negatively impacting their trade of goods, hurting their economy, and putting themselves at risk of contracting the virus.
- They are losing control by doing this. This pandemic is putting a lot of stress on them, as they are losing control over the virus, the economy, and the people.

Now for the end result. Their plan is "successful" and now they will have world domination.
- They already have world dominaton.
- Their plan is a failure and they intentionally made it fail. They managed to cause chaos, and now are trying desperately to NOT "control" the populace.
- The world has been left changed yet unfazed by the virus. People arent scared of it anymore. People are learning how to take care of themselves. People are feeling better prepared for another pandemic in the future. People dont care about the regulations. They just taught the populace how to control THEMSELVES.

It's a dumb and unnecessary stupid plan, and they are not as dumb as people seem to think they are. If they wanted to control the populace, they could do way better.

"If there were treatments against cancer, and i believe there sure are, they would be held secret.

Youou can effectivley treat cancer, e.g. to remove it completely, but hold it secret.

You actually make it public and still want to make lots of money, but noone probably could afford it, except the rich.
It still wouldnt be lucrative enough, at least not as lucrative as Case 1.

Useful approach, but you should add a few points to the checklist to identify conspiracies or actually select non-conspiracy statements : 1. general logic ( Are there any inner paradoxes?, like that it would be irrational to withhold a cancer curing medication as you could earn billions with it or given negligence due to the huge amount of possibly involved persons or your approach in correlation with rich people. )
2. objectivity and falsification (Is there a measurable approach to the statement or would it be possible ? Can it be falsified? )
3. outer paradoxes (any inconveniences with existing empirically gained data or proven simulations based on them?)
4. prediction and proof ( Is there any direct data showing the existence of the content of the statement? )

If a statement/theory, etc. fulfills all of these points, it should be considered confirmed until differing evidence emerges.

Sorry, but this video is poorly made. It claims to want to be a video you send to your conspiracy theorist friends, yet has an extremely condescending tone and does not actually address the issues that lead people to believe in these sort of things, it only succeeds in reaffirming already ingrained beliefs (whether it be that "all conspiracy theories are BS!" or "I believe that XYZ!".

The fact of the matter is, people do conspire, and people from all walks of life, rich people are no exception. The reason rich people often get the brunt of them is because of the influence their money grants them. Two average joes are pretty limited in how they can conspire, they might be able to conspire to rob a 7/11, or perhaps cheat a casino, or other such things. People worth billions have the resources and connections needed to do much more however. Wealthy conspirators may be able to do things like bribe politicians or other key influencers, launder millions of dollars, or other such things. I personally think it's naive if one truly believes that wealthy people don't conspire, especially when you see them getting busted for it on a regular basis (how often do you here reports of money laundering, insurance fraud, etc.)? Dismissing everything is just as harmful as schizo flat-earth reptilian overlord claims, perhaps even more so, as you are letting people get away with political and/or financial corruption. People need to make up their own damn mind, it's not some zero sum game where you either have to believe that powerful people are angels incapable of doing no wrong, or that the earth is flat and ruled over by lizard overlords.

My rule of thumb, and I think is much better than what is suggested in this video (though I am biased) is.

1 - Is this conspiracy grounded? i.e. within reality, even if it seems implausible.
2 - Does someone(s) benefit in some way from it?
3 - Is there a means/motive/etc?

If you answered yes to all three, you should immediately be suspicious, and the theory should be looked at critically.

This logic is flawed in so many different ways, and is so open to interpretation it can't seriously be classed as a debunking tool.
What might be a better way to phrase it would be: do rich people want/benefit from something they can't tell everyone else (even if other people benefit too).

1) Suppressed cancer cure - Rich people with an investment in Big Pharma and current medical practices (industry of astronomical proportions) might not want a free cure available so they can maintain a monopoly and stay rich. Firstly, Steve Jobs wasn't in that industry; and secondly, even the people with investments in Big Pharma would only have access to their paid treatments, and might not be able to use suppressed methods. Not saying there definitely is a suppressed cure, but you can't just debunk it by saying Steve Jobs died of cancer.
2) Chemtrails - For climate control, deflecting sun rays. Rich people want to stay alive and possibly even save the planet from destruction (possibly for selfish reasons). A few chemicals in the air in some places certainly isn't ideal, but perhaps necessary for survival. It could also be done in places away from the rich and powerful so it won't affect them.
3) World ending is too vague to be either proven or debunked without further info. The Flat Earth conspiracy, however, seems to have no clear benefit or practical use to anyone. I'd say that one is fairly easily debunked.

I think this video has some flawed points, namely in that the guiding line that calls all rich and powerful people isn't actually calling on a single united front.

For example, Steve Jobs doesn't function well as an indicator that cancer doesn't have a cure that's simply being suppressed;
His expertise was in technology, and he actively turned down modern treatments in favor of more "alternative" medicine for at least some of the duration of his battle with cancer. And while yeah sure, he was rich, does that necessarily help him get in on the conspiracy taking place in the pharmaceutical industry?

Further, that seems to assume that "the cure for cancer" is just... something that's trivially easy to both create and suppress. It's not at all unrealistic that cancer research can be kept ongoing without finding definite conclusions due to the inherent difficulty of the problem that is curing cancer, and it could be rather easy for the companies funding that research to snuff out anything in the meantime they see that might lead to cures instead of treatments (because corporations can't sell medicine to someone who isn't sick. a patient cured is a patient lost).
Pharmaceutical corporations have the means and the motive, and while I'm not saying they have suppressed a cure for cancer, because I wouldn't assert something like that so baselessly, I am absolutely saying that assuming they wouldn't because 'rich people get cancer too' is almost laughable

Another way to debunk a conspiracy is just to ask if it's practical:

Is it practically possible to cover up a moon landing? No, because that would require thousands of people to be completely silent for decades, which just isn't possible.

Is it practically possible that vaccines have microchips? No, because those microchips could have malfunctioned and revealed themselves, and all the people (likely thousands) who presumably developed/inserted them into vaccines would have had to stay silent, which just isn't possible.

Is it practical that Kurzgesagt is a global organization hellbent on educating the populace for the sake of intellectual world domination? Okay... that's a tricky one, jury's still out on that one.

My personal checklist for 'Is this conspiracy viable in any way?' goes like this:

1. How many people are involved? If the answer is something like 'every scientist on Earth', 'NASA' (plus all it's sub-contractors and businisses working for them) or several gouvernments (especially those who really don't like each other) are involved, it's pretty unlikely. The sheer number of witnesses would lead to leaks. I mean we learned about some true conspiracies from whistle blowers - The AIDS contaminated blood packeges spring to mind - or MK Ultra. And there, the number of co conspirators was miniscule to now.

2. How ist it maintained? Who pays? Who does what to keep the thing afloat. If you need the budget of a large country - then it's probably bs.

3. What's the gain? If it's some nebolous 'agenda' nobody really knows, or if it's evil for the sake of evil - yeah. BS-alarm. We had a scandal about overpriced FFP2-masks where I live. Basically some politician with deep pockets got those pockets lined by a mask-producer to let the state buy them for ten times the regular price.. That's a gain. One guy - probably one of two guys who knew the ins and outs of this conspiracy got a lot of money. But 'it's the Illuminati Agenda' to do - yeah? What?...

4. Bonus: If it's crazier than an average James Bond plot - it's probably also BS.

5. If NOBODY can know about the conspiracy because THEY have all the power and money to keep it secret - HOW THE F*** did some random internet-warrior get the TRUTH (tm)? THEY literally can kill everyone opposing them and their family and let it look like ritual suicide.... So why on earth (flat or otherwise) can those people post their BS on the internet - which is obviously also controlled by THEM?

But yeah - on the 'are rich people affecte' is a pretty good one, I didn't think of really...

If we could just talk someone out of it... See, conspiracy theories are not simply believed out of a lack of better explanations - but usually because people feel abandoned, exploited, disoriented, disempowered and meaningless. If you take a closer look, the theory does not just explain the world - it also describes the person agreeing to the description. You will find that conspiracy theories not only tell you something about all mighty, malevolent antagonists - but also about what it means for a human to "recognize this truth", that is the conspiracy theory. The person who awakens to the reality of a conspiracy theory has suddenly regained some of the power they lost: they are no longer "trapped in the matrix", they have overcome the "brainwashing by the media", they see finally clear, where others are still trapped. In spreading the truth, they are the heroes in a war against the malevolent elite. The theory further tells you precisely who is to blame for your bad situation - without any ambiguity. In short: to accept a conspiracy theory can mean to regain power, orientation and meaning. Vice versa, to abandon the theory means to give up orientation, meaning and power. So when you're trying to talk someone out of it, it's not a matter presenting a reasonable argumentation - it's a matter of untethering their persona, killing their inner hero and having them face the ambiguous void that is reality. Which might explain, why talking someone out of it is a bullshit attempt.

There is a worrying converse to this, which could explain some of the credence afforded to some conspiracy theories: if the theory turned out to be true, would this confer a significant BENEFIT to very rich or powerful people? Nearly all investigations into human behaviour (legal, historical etc), involve a 'qui bono' or 'who benefits' element (colloquially, 'follow the money'). It doesn't prove such a conspiracy theory but it does explain why it will endure and is to some extent rational, or at least not completely irrational.

The other reason they sometimes cannot be dismissed offhand is that evidence to both prove or disprove it is suspiciously absent. Usually this is probably purely circumstantial but there might sometimes be other reasons to believe that the evidence has been 'managed' in some way by parties involved in the conspiracy (of course in an actual conspiracy, that would seem like an important part of the plan).

Either way, this type of conspiracy theory remains 'reasonably mysterious' because there is both qui bono concerns and no satisfactory rational basis to confirm it either as fact, as a legitimate theory or as false. In other words, it's probably not very sensible to share them on facebook, but at the same time you're not a crackpot for privately thinking there's something in them. I imagine you can pick your own examples!

As a disclaimer, I don't believe or even subscribe to these theories and would only argue them for the sake of arguing, as I am right now. Are all conspiracies wrong? Probably not.

But that claim holds about as much water as the claim of rich people dying of cancer proving against your first issue.

Again, the idea that rich people breathing in the air is just as terrible of an argument as plenty of others. Rich people tend to support businesses that provide an asinine amount of pollution in the air and water. How often do we actually see them give a damn, even when said pollution isn't all that far from them, relatively speaking? A wind from a city nearby can bring a level of pollution to them at levels that can't be detected by our basic senses?

Not to mention, we see the 'trails' aircraft leave behind sometimes. Much less than earlier on. How can we say there is none when these trails are what are being referred to?

The last one being an issues I've had to repeat myself on over and over again, including on issues like planet X. Why do we still believe these things when they pretty much never happen? I guess people want to keep starting things!

I will listen to those who know more, or even enough, but would never 100% trust what they say as truths. Nobody should.

I love you guys, and I realize this is really old, but it is complete BS. Every single one of your suggestions is so completely an example of a raw man argument that it almost feels insulting. Steve Jobs had a neuroendocrine tumor on his pancreas. This is highly treatable and the treatment could even be considered a cure. However, it wasn't the lack of treatment availability that prevented him from recovering, it was his own ego and his decision NOT to take the cure--he thought he could fix it himself. Hopefully, you see how irrelevant and foolish this makes item 1. There is no way of knowing how many rich/influential people have been cured of cancer with cures unavailable to the general public so your characterization is both false and ironic. The ideas behind chem-trails are largely misrepresented by your claims. Sure, the strange belief that chemtrails are doing population control is foolish, but the idea that chem-trails provide a realistic and useful means of reflecting sunlight that could have direct positive results for the outer layer of our magnetosphere is not unreasonable and would affect everyone. So you were foolish to pick a false argument for the second support of your theory. This leads us to number 3 which was your actual goal: an admirable attempt to ease fear. But the point of the matter is that the end of the world could be right around the corner and it would affect everyone. But lots of natural disasters that could occur from Global Climate Change have "emergency" plans accessible to the richest people. Entire bunkers stacked with food exist for the ultra-rich just in case. Again, your characterization of the conspiracy theory falls flat. You can do better than this.

Perhaps what you should attack is the notion of conspiracies with harmful intent. If you can explain how there is not as much malice in the world as some people (the one's with malice in them) think, the need for conspiratorial malice fails. Or perhaps you could attack the idea that no secret is safe if more than 1 person knows the truth. Surely if it is a real conspiracy, someone will expose it. There are lots of ways of attacking conspiracy theories, especially the foolish ones. But evaluating them with respect to rich people is fallacious, insulting, and quite frankly less than what we have come to expect from Kurzgesagt.

I don't understand how people actually believe alot of this stuff. Despite the fact that most of these theories have an overwhelming amount of evidence against them, a simple look at some of the underlying logic and you'll find massive holes in logic. A common flaw that most theories use that should immediately make them very questionable is that they involve some large amount of people or groups hiding something. An example is COVID-19. Some people still think its a hoax, despite the fact that literally tens of thousands of health experts across the world have taken a look at this thing under a microscope. What do you think, that they were able to convince every single person with an understanding of microbiology and a microscope to get in on this hoax? Highly implausible. Even if you relaxed this ridiculous assumption, how would so many people be able to keep a thing like this a secret? There are just way too many holes in it. Of course anything no matter how ridiculous it seems is possible, but the fact that it relies on so many bold and illogical assumptions should basically render it as having a 99.9% chance of being false.

A friend of mine has a vauxhall combo van..

The steering linkage broke whilst he was driving. And he could not steer the van.. Luckily, No one was hurt.

I emailed Stephen norman, the ceo of vauxhall to complain of the dangerous fault and he referred me to a secretary, Angela kelly.
We arranged for the part to be delivered by me to a vauxhall dealership in wolverhampton so it can be sent to opel in Germany for testing..

Their testing revealed that there had definitely been no manufacturing fault".. And it was therefore not their problem..

I pointed out that if there was no manufacturing fault, and yet the problem had still occurred, then logic dictates that the fault MUST be in the design..
Therefore all of these vans like this must be susceptible to the possibility of the same problem occuring, along with any cars with the same steering design..

First, instead of being focused on logic, evidence, probability, and historical precedent, you develop a new way to determine truth not applicable to anything else, and we are supposed to blindly accept it? One of the examples you came up with "Adolphin" doesn't even meet your criteria. Does that mean you believe Adolphin is real? Or, do you lack belief because it is illogical, has no evidence to support it, is highly improbable, and there is no historical precedent that lends credibility to the idea?



Second, the term "conspiracy theorist" is used as an ad hominem attack (specifically guilt by association) which only serves to reinforce the confirmation bias at the stage of gathering information. This is every bit as ignorant as simply believing any wild an improbable claim you hear. If we really want to combat outlandish conspiracy theories, why not educate people on how we can use reason to determine what is true? Third, there is nothing wrong with speculation, as long as you accept it is speculation. This is how we form hypotheses which can then be tested using the scientific method. The problem is belief, especially zealous conviction, without any supporting evidence. Again, not being willing to consider ideas is every bit as harmful as blindly accepting them.



Last, we act as if conspiracy is some absurd notion, even though there are plenty of evidence of actual conspiracies, and in other contexts we don't have the same level of skepticism (which would be special pleading). If it is so absurd, why can one be charged with conspiracy to commit murder or conspiracy to defraud the government? Isn't it logically inconsistent not to consider the possibility of one, but not the question the other?



As for conspiracies themselves, the official government's narrative of 9/11 meets the criteria of a conspiracy. The definition of conspiracy is "The act of two or more persons, called conspirators, working secretly to obtain some goal, usually understood with negative connotations." Note that the negative connotation is not always necessary, or if present could depend on one's perspective. This would mean the assassination of Abraham Lincoln is a known conspiracy, with nine co-conspirators being hung. So would Watergate. So would the entire scope of intelligence agencies such as the CIA or MI6. Due to the obvious need for secrecy, the writing and signing of our declaration of independence meets the criteria of a conspiracy. You can go back in history as far as you'd like.... the assassination of Julius Caesar is a confirmed conspiracy.



Here are a few more conspiracies which have been proven: Operation GLADIO, Operation Mockingbird, COINTELPRO, Operation Northwoods, the Tuskegee syphilis experiments, the Bay of Pigs invasion, US Black sites and torture of detainees, the Bologna massacre, Operation Ocean Spray, the Iran Contra scandal, Operation Mongoose, the price fixing of diamonds by De Beers, the Dryfus affair, the Downing Street memo, ECHELON, the Enron scandal, Fast and Furious scandal, the creation of the Federal Reserve Act which passed in 1913, the Gulf of Tonkin incident, human trafficking, large pedophile networks which have been exposed, the Franklin scandal, widespread abuse of children from Catholic priests and the resulting coverup, Operation Ajax, Operation Cyclone, Operation Chaos, Operation Himmler, Operation Midnight Climax, Operation Paperclip, MKULTRA, Operation PBSUCCESS, the Pentagon papers, Operation Show White, the Phoebus cartel, the Pheonix program, Project FUBELT..... and on and on and on.



None of this is speculation; all of it is proven with evidence. Considering the large amount of conspiracies which have been confirmed throughout history, it is idiotic to dismiss something on the basis of it being a conspiracy. This is by far the least thought out and worst video you have ever made. The aversion to the notion of conspiracy is anti-intellectual at best, and limits the range of acceptable thought at worst. You should be utterly ashamed.

In mainstream political circles anyone who talks about conspiracies is instantly ridiculed, usually with insults about tinfoil hats
and prescription medication. This ugly habit is ignorant and immature since even a little open-minded study reveals there have been many conspiracies throughout history and that many of them had a great effect.
Common examples are emperor Nero's burning of Rome which was blamed on the Christians, at the time a persecuted minority, and Hitler's Reichtag fire which was blamed on communists.

A more recent example: in 1999 Moscow police caught FSB (Russian intelligence) agents red-handed planting bombs in
Moscow apartment buildings. These bombings were blamed on Chechen rebels and used by Russia as justification for its invasion
and destruction of Chechnya. Sounds familiar?
Most Americans would have no problem believing that those pesky Russians would be up to such dirty tricks. But when it comes to their own country? Forget it.

Assassinations, shootings and bombings are further examples. Whenever one of those events takes place somewhere around the world,  many people suspect a false flag operation, but in the U.S. assassins, shooters and bombers are always supposed to be crazed loners. The U.S. is of course completely immune to conspiracies. The U.S. government would never dream of harming its own citizens for political gain. Or so the American population believes, who are conditioned to always blindly believe the official version of events forced in their faces by their government and mainstream media. 

The problem with Americans is that they never see conspiracy. The problem with for example the French is that they see conspiracy everywhere. Both of them are wrong. "Conspiracy theory" has become an ugly term that is used to denigrate a theory, labeling it as something that must be false. 

What is the opposite of a conspiracy theory? The official version of events, of course. The world so needs to know this. When I was young and hung out with punks and hippies, most of my friends subscribed to any number of conspiracy theories. I even entertained a few myself at times. Now I've grown up, a bit, I can see most of them for what they are, and it is quite apparent to me now, why they appeal to certain groups of people.
1. People who feel downtrodden or supressed, perhaps by domineering parents or other authority figures, develop a distrust of authority, and the 'status quo', and will often latch onto anything that might prove these figures wrong, and somehow elevate themselves, as being 'someone in the know'.
2. People who have a strong emotional bias (prejudice) against a certain group, be they 'rich people', other races, people with certain sexual preferences, or, sometimes even the disabled, will, sometimes try to justify separation from these groups, by , somehow blaming them for any number of things, and will often embellish the truth, or even, make up, and propagate a story, or set of ideas specifically designed to justify their prejudice.
3. Mentally insecure or paranoid people can quite readily accept many conspiracy theories, because they will often seem to align with some of their own paranoid assumptions.
I have noticed, over many years, that someone who believes one conspiracy theory will generally entertain the lot, which really underlines the idea that belief in these theories is more an act of 'rebellion' than the result of open minded analytical thought. It seems that once someone decides they want to believe conspiracy theories, they become quite closed minded towards any argument that might contradict it, even if the theory can easily be disproved. Once again, rebellion. It takes maturity, and honesty, to admit when one really doesn't know, or when one might be wrong.

Usually the easiest way to tell when someone is a conspiracy nutter for me is based on a few simple notes I jot down about them.

Do they throw out "CONSPIRACEEEHHHHHH!" As a convenient excuse for why they can't not now, nor ever provide evidence EVER!?

Does their claim just so happen to be a recycled version of some older claim that's basically the same thing that everyone else got wrong but they just so happened to have gotten it right even though everyone else says the same thing whenever the "real nutters" bring up the exact same (only slightly varied) unproved claim?

Do they make endless claims on end, followed by endless excuses when those claims have holes poked in them?

Ultimately I could go on. These aren't shotgun barrel questions that prove someone is a nutter. It's just a few of the normal questions I ask myself. Ultimately the most foolproof ways of telling that people are full of shit are quite easy.

The truth is so easy to remember that it's forgettable and it NEVER results in emotional tirades if someone doesn't believe you aside from the annoyance that comes with trying to make people understand the ACTUAL truth when their "truth" is bark raving irrational nonsense. Even then think about it. Have any of you ever gotten angry whenever someone questioned something true that you believe? Nope. Never. Nor would you need to? If it's true then your opinion on the matter is irrelevant so there's no need to throw a hissy fit when you can't demonstrate your claim. For example, evolutionists may get annoyed trying to explain to creationists how creationism is garbage, we can even act smug but we don't care at the end of the day if the person we're talking to wakes up and smells the roses. There's a natural confidence that comes with being right. When you're right you're not the one who winds up bitching and whinging going "But but but you gotta understand maaannnnn........"

Liars need easily digestable scripts, they resort to fits when you don't believe them and they tried to hide their frustration by pretending "I don't care that you think I'm crazy" is either true when they say it nor does it not reflect their invincible ignorance. It totally does by the way. People who don't care that people think they're nuts in my experience are usually doing so to protect their precious beliefs. People who care about truth CARE about whether or not people think they're crazy. People who are crazy need to act like it's everyone else who's nuts to make themselves feel good about chasing "da troof!" because if they realised what a ridiculous waste of time their "investigations" are then they'd have to face those uncomfortable feels you get when you realise you're not actually smart, and you are in fact a buffoon who bought into utter nonsense getting conned by shiesters. So it's easier to just keep on keeping on as you keep the logic out.

People who care about the truth care about people thinking that they're nuts not for "conformity" but because we don't want to wind up insane! People who are full of shit care about only listening to those who tickle their ears because their claims can't stand up to everyone else's criticisms. And their claims are always backed up by a whole lot of talk yet not suprisingly no technological boons, nor any advancements to society. Just a whole lot of empty assertions followed by "YOU'RE IN ON IT!"

I'm not advocating for any specific theory you've highlighted (in fact, I'm usually skeptical of them myself), but using the pretense that "if it affects rich people then it's most likely wrong" is a poor way to debunk them. I could easily use the same logic on climate change and say "well, rich people will be affected by long term climate change too, so there is no difference in climate". Now of course due to scientific study, we know climate change is very real and has very real, long-lasting effects. I'm sure you would agree to this. It's also important to realize that in the rich are conspiring to do something to defend an industry (like the cure for cancer), they're doing it for profit - not because they're keeping the cure for themselves. Need I even mention Martin Shkreli as a primary example of this?

I think a better way to debunk conspiracy theories is to get a second and third opinion on the matter. If you Google "chemtrails" and look at the myriad of links and pay close attention to who doing the talking, then based on critical thinking, you can make your own conclusion as to how credible the theory is.

This video completely misses the root of the problem. There is a serious misunderstanding as to HOW conspiracy theorists think, and WHY they think the way they do.

WHY: People who feel like they've lost control of their own life tend to look for a reason as to why this had happened. Conspiracy theories are the go-to explanation because they imply that a greater power (most often their government) has assumed control of their life through questionable practices. This makes their conspiracy theory of choice exceptionally personal.

HOW: Because the said conspiracy theory "explains" why they hadn't been successful in life, they will defend it _at all costs_. They will perform the most extraordinary mental gymnastics to justify their belief in a theory. Regardless of whether logic permits them to. Let's take the chemtrail example; I mean, sure... Obama and Putin breathe the same air. BUT a conspiracy theorist will probably resort to an alternative explanation. Something along the lines of "Obama and Putin have a chemtrail antidote" or "nanobots in their blood expel chemtrail molecules" or any other fantastical explanation one can conceive of to uphold the credibility of a theory.

These people DO NOT subscribe to the laws of logic. Which means your proposed system of debunking conspiracy theories will likely have a success rate of less than 0.1%.

There are so many holes in this logic, and I believe this simplification promotes close-mindedness..

For example: being financially rich and politically powerful doesn't imply having access to hidden or desired information.. there may be a slight correlation but it's dangerous to assume it's causation. Rich people are some of the unhappiest and unhealthiest because they buy into the illusion of the materialist American Dream. I consider it immoral to propagate the idea that material wealth and societal success equates with access to knowledge and Truth with a capital 'T'.
For example I know the "cure" for cancer and all I had to do was research and objective analysis.. drum roll... it's called preventative medicine- living a healthy lifestyle free from toxins and pollution. It's easier said than done, but so is conventional treatment for cancer. It's not opinion that there is a built-in incentive structure (profit) for medical institutions and pharmaceutical companies to downplay this truth and push for reactive treatment like chemo and radiation. For evidence look up the documentary "What the Health" for example. Whether that is considered a conspiracy is partially a question of semantics. Large public institutions openly admit to doing this manipulation so I'd say it's just plain and simple manipulation, greed and immorality. Perhaps people like to cling to the idea of conspiracies for a cure to treat cancer because they're too lazy to stay healthy on their own.
In any case, I don't believe the logic in this video really helps people sort out useful truth.

I really love so much of Kurzgesagt's videos, but I find this one to be somewhat of a failure. I think it offers an opportunity for many real issues to be thrown into the conspiracy theory pile. The problem with conspiracy theories is not that they involve people that are rich or that have power. The problem is that such theories assume that people in such positions have bad intentions. Usually, nobody has bad intentions but instead just selfish ones. So, if you consider the reality that people might be guided by selfish interests and possibly not even by more enlightened self interested values, you might see how easily people in such positions could do some terrible stuff. People motivated by profit or personal ambition for the short term that forgo long-term goals could do something like raise the price of an AIDS drug to an unreasonable level just because you can. If Steve Jobs could've paid, say, $50 million for access to a cure while exposing said cure to the rest of humanity, the industry harboring the cure would make $50 million at the cost of untold billions of future research funding. It's obvious which option they'd choose. What Kurzgesagt gets wrong here is that, in this 'conspiracy theory,' the industry exists to support a sustained income for itself, not to make extremely risky and inconsistent bursts of cash here and there by preying on rare, sufficiently desperate and wealthy individuals. They have to protect their cash cow. (This is presupposing that most people who've just narrowly escaped death by utilizing a secret cure would willingly risk their new lease on life by attempting to expose it to the masses—which is, in my estimation, an astronomical probability. Are there stupid conspiracy theories? Sure, loads. And your question really does expose a lot of them as, well, conspiracy theories. But one of the examples you mentioned is actually true to a degree. The "conspiracy theory" I'm talking about is the one about a "secret" cure for cancer that is withheld because the pharma industry wouldn't make any money off of it.

While not a miracle cure that completely destroys every cancer cell in existence, it is a supporting drug that actually makes cancer cells more susceptible to chemotherapy. And it is dirt-cheap. Furthermore, its supporting effect has been known for over a decade! The drug is Methadone, an opioid that is usually used in addiction rehabs.

There was an episode of stern tv (a German TV/News show that often reports about current and controversial issues) dedicated to this just about a month ago. You can find it here on youtube. It's in German though, and I don't know if there are subtitles available. Because of this report this "miracle drug" has become somewhat better known.

Someone reading my comment might say "So, if that show was just about a month ago, how could Kurzgesagt have known about it? The video was posted almost two years ago" - that's exactly the point. Not a lot of people know, even though the effect the drug has on cancer cells has been known for over a decade. Imagine the number of lives that could have been saved in that timespan...Truly, the pharma industry needs to be far more monitored and far harder punished for such practices. Look up John Oliver's report on dialysis here on youtube and I think you too will come to the conclusion, that nowadays the pharma industry is trying to keep us sick for profit.

The third example doesn't work. In the first two conspiracy examples, humanity themselves are the purported cause of whatever secret thing is going on. Thus, the rich/powerful people behind such supposed events would be effected by their own schemes. In the third example, the purported cause is OUTSIDE of humanity, being things like divine acts or alien invasions.

For instance, alien invasions are caused by aliens. So it would be better to ask: "Would an alien invasion negatively effect the rich and/or powerful ALIENS among whatever supposed race are doing the invading?"

The answer? Well, if the aliens live in a democracy with a mass media similar to ours and general emotions similar to ours, it does actually turn out to be yes. Invading a low tech planet to get at some resources you could likely find on plenty of other, uninhabited planets would be enormously unpopular. If the aliens live in a different form of system, then there are no doubt some societal configurations that would make it alright for them to invade us.

As for apocalypse/ragnarok/etc, depending on the religion its being based on, you could potentially argue that is in the hands of ex-humans, but for all intents and purposes whether a religious end of the world happens is not in the hands of any rich/powerful humans who physically live on the planet.

My statement (in a nutshell) is here that one should deeply look into a matter before accepting or rejecting it.

Conspiracy theories have become so problematic because both sides are viewing it too simplistic. Most of the topics are hugely important and deserve to be thought about and analyzed thoroughly. Neglecting to look at some topics, just because it is not confirmed by mass media yet and labeling it as conspiracy theory, is not really helpful and doesn’t do much more than building a barrier between healthy curiosity and the daring of seeking information though not confirmed from institutions yet.
On the other hand, breaking these complex topics down on to a scenario of a few puppet masters, who control the whole world, is just as unthoughtful as the conspiracy-theory-phobia. Believing in a few bad guys who stamp on the naïve world habitants, is dangerous as it doesn’t allow the mind to go to the core of a problem and to analyze it through. Also it causes a state of fear and helplessness in the viewer’s mind, which doesn’t help with the process of resolving problematic topics at all, but just causes powerlessness.
I see, some addressed topics in the conspiracy theory debate, more as actual problems deriving from complex dynamics. A French sociologist and philosopher Michel Foucault has an interesting theory about discourses. I really would engage both parties- Conspiracy theory spreaders and conspiracy theory phobics- to look up his literature and get a feeling of how twisted this stuff really can be. So that it neither spreads fear nor it shuts the people off, who sense that maybe the government is not always handling in the best interest of the people.  To Kurzgesagt +UCsXVk37bltHxD1rDPwtNM8Q : Please think twice (and tripple and so on) before stating such big claims (and yes, even ideas accepted by mainstream, mass media and institutions can be just big claims). Especially by topics which are hugely dodgy, like the conspiracy-theory-one. What disturbed me the most, is your poor method of debunking those theories. I don't have a problem of debunking, but doing so inteligently is highly importand. Especially when you are in a position of a trusted advisor for many viewers of yours.

But thanks for your other videos though, some are great and really fun to watch!

Depopulation theories - unlikely, due to current socio-economic structure we live in.

I like this, it's pretty good, but I think there are two assumptions that are made that could be used to counter argue these arguments.


First, Steve Jobs could have made enemies among the rich and famous that we don't know about who decided to withhold the drug from them. This only makes sense though if only a few rich and famous people die of cancer, and not if the amount of rich people who die is proportional to less rich people who die.


 Also, it's possible that a very select few hold the secret to a cancer cure, and so no-one really notices that they don't die, but it would be extremely difficult to keep a cure for cancer known to a select few. Also, there's probably no one cure for cancer.

Finally, with the doomsday thing, the argument assumes rational agents. There are plenty of people in the world who would think that causing the apocalypse would be the right thing, either through mental illness, delusion, being deceived or a very different world view. For example, some Christians think that they have a role in fulfilling Biblical prophecy and bringing about the end times, and it's not a stretch to think that eco-terrorists or a dictator could also want to bring about an apocalypse/extinction of humans/destruction of enemies.


 Obviously the video does say their rebuttal only works for some theories, but I just thought I'd mention a few things that I thought of while watching the video.

There is no miracle cure for cancer, but there is a better treatment alternative. Cannabinoids found in marijuana are more effective, less destructive, and far cheaper, than radiation and chemotherapy. Of course, surgically removing the cancer first, when possible is the best course of action. You cannot patent a plant, but you could synthesize and patent its compounds, if cost effective. Cancer is caused by chromosomal damage by toxins, disease, and/or radiation. When the right gene of DNA is damaged, it triggers cells to reproduce wildly causing tumors, and the cancerous cells get spread through the body via the bloodstream.  CBD and THC used in conjunction, triggers the "off switch" of the epigenome for that particular gene, and effectively prevents and reverses cancer. Radiation and chemo are used in the hopes that more radiation will destroy that gene in all the cancerous cells. The problem is that it damages the rest of your DNA along with it, ages your tissues drastically, and makes cancer more likely to occur in other parts of the body. But hey, that just promotes job security for oncologists. Healthcare in the US is more about creating dependent customers than curing disease. Like radiation and chemotherapy, cannabis oil treatment is no guarantee. Unlike radiation, it can't be targeted at a specific area and localized. What is challenging is making sure it works on all the cancerous cells faster than the tumors spread, but the same applies to chemo. There's a limit to how saturated with THC and CBD your blood can get, but there's no limit to radiation exposure. At a certain point, the radiation will kill you faster than the cancer though. If it doesn't cure you, you just made your final days miserably excruciating. If you beat the cancer, you still destroyed your health and shortened the life of your organs. There is no money in cannabis oil for big pharma, because you can grow and make it yourself. This isn't myth at all, but thoroughly proven science. Instead, pharmaceutical companies are investing R&D into immunotherapy treatments to get your body's immune system to target and attack tumorous cells. That they can patent and secure profits from.

I see a lot of hate on this video - to be fair they DID say that it doesn't work with all conspiracies. I think this video was just to point out that through a minimum amount of critical thinking you can weigh the likelihood of a conspiracy being true or not.

Example: The world is flat.
Do scientists, teachers, astronauts, government, corporate news and the majority of the world benefit in any way from deceiving you? No? The world isn't flat.

But I do agree that a little more thought could have been put into this video.

YOUR FIRST ARGUMENT DOESN'T MAKE SENSE

Say there was a SECRET cure for cancer, how would Steve Jobs know about it?
Only because he was rich and influential? If there is a secret cure for cancer, it is definitely an EXTREMELY well-kept secret that only a handful of people know. And - guess what - you would probably not find these few people in the TECH sector (e.g. Steve Jobs), but in the PHARMA industry. Isn't that obvious? If the insiders would ever use the secret cure to heal their own cancer, nobody would ever know. It would just look as if they never had cancer in the first place.

Spreading this nonsense argument as a "counterproof" is simply a stupefaction of the people. How presumptuous of you to call this conspiracy theory "stupid". Look who's talking! Our economic system does in fact create bad incentives, and it is indeed imaginable that pharma companies would keep a cure for cancer secret. Manufacturers earn more from non-durable products than from sustainable, long-life products (look up 'planned obsolescence'), simply because they can sell more. In a similar manner, pharma companies have a HUGE financial incentive to make us ill, simply because they don't make their money with healthy people, but with people that are ill.

I'm afraid that this "razor"-style process isn't effective for scratching the itch that conspiracy theories provide. I'm a very torn individual when it comes to conspiracy theories. Information can sound plausible when organized by an intelligent individual and may even appear to stand up to small amounts of scrutiny, causing contagious panic in the minds of those unable or unwilling to completely investigate the the truth. Aside from that, your single qualifier can actually be counter-argued by any conspiracy theorist angry enough at the "financial elite" by making roundabout claims to justify how and why said elite would cover up things like a cure for cancer or oncoming and inevitable global catastrophe.

If you want to ignore a conspiracy effectively, tell the theorist who is arguing with you that the online evidence they have been presented is public domain, available to be under the examination of credible professionals. If they say they don't trust that the evidence has been examined or that claims of them being false are cover-ups, tell them you believe they should study the conspiracy in more depth to uncover new information or otherwise quit spreading poorly-detailed information that is intentionally confusing.

If so many people are so eager to theorize about conspiracies, they need to apply the scientific process to it themselves just like anyone has to do with physics.

Honestly a little surprised by this one. I've been watching the videos on this channel for a couple weeks now and I've noticed some traits of said videos that I really enjoy: 1) A humanitarian approach: I find most if not all of your videos contain a positive, uplifting message 2) Proof, proof, proof: the professionals your team refers to always pass my (albeit brief and unprofessional) investigation into their credibility 3) A focus on enlightening and bringing together both the audience and humanity as a whole.
Great traits to have in your videos and the main reason I keep coming back. With that being said I was EXTREMELY disappointed by the utter lack of these 3 things and the dismissive attitude towards the message contained behind it. Although I do agree that the internet is a breeding ground for ignorance, and that almost everything on it should be taken with a large dose of skepticism, it is clearly not always the case. Would it be true to say your channel is proliferating ignorance? No, quite the opposite right?. Remember that the internet is also a source for otherwise overlooked or unavailable but incredibly useful information. Also please note the amount of legislature and government policy trying to control the internet.
Next, I was not fan of the: "Does it affect the rich/powerful" approach. How is that a reasonable starting platform for this kind of discussion? Those are EXACTLY the type of people who could easily hide, scapegoat or otherwise assume plausible deniability. Example: How do you know that the president/world leaders are aware of something such as chemtrails? There are plenty of doctors, scientists, aviation experts, chemists etc who work for wealthy but not humanitarian concerned companies. It's just as likely that Obama is in same boat as we are in terms of enforced ignorance. I mean, lets be honest, money rules the world, not the people we call our leaders. How much more likely is someone to kill someone else quietly for money rather than most other reasons? And how many times in our past have we had world leaders come to us preaching about their ignorance to mass genocide, drug abuse in their political parties etc? Now I'm not saying I know the answers or that the crew at Kurzgesagt is wrong, in fact there's a great chance that you're right but COME ON. After all those informative, positive, fair and otherwise awesome videos, you guys would release something as one sided and biased as this? Disappointed. Very disappointed :(.

People who are richer tend to live longer than people who are poorer (an incredibly well-known fact). Rich people can afford to remove themselves from locations that are ecologically or environmentally compromised, or can just pay enough money to avoid having such compromising occur. The world may end soon for any number of reasons.

1 - There is no current cure for cancer. Literally everyone has cancer cells in their body. The disease we call cancer occurs when those cancer cells that already exist experience a malfunction in their division mechanisms that causes them to divide uncontrollably. Although it is true that there is no profit in curing cancer, and in our society if you cant make money from it, it simply won't happen. It's just a product of the system we live in.
2 - The chemtrails thing is hard to gather data for because the atmosphere is too big, so it's impossible to determine where harmful chemicals in the air come from with our current technology. Until there is some way to gather reliable data on the subject, we should just withhold judgment.
3 - Various people have been claiming the world was going to end for literally all of humanity's history. If the world as we know it were to end, it wouldn't be because of some evil secret cabal. It would likely be due to a computer glitch that causes an accidental nuclear exchange, or maybe we're just too stupid to change our energy generation methods and allow the Earth to continue to heat until the ocean currents shut down (Thus shutting down delivery of oxygenated water from the surface to the bottom of the ocean), causing anaerobic bacteria at the seafloor to bloom and release poisonous gases that would wipe out probably 99% of life on Earth. This has happened once before. Even if a nuclear exchange occurs where every nuclear weapon on Earth was triggered, humanity would still survive, though just barely. The second scenario is the only real end of the world scenario with a considerable likelihood of happening that we know of right now.

One thing I will say is that it's not a stretch of the mind to think that powerful people might come together and make a plan, but that plan doesn't include ending the world. One cannot make money off of a dead world. Instead, those with power tend to act to maintain and expand that power. The difference between now and the empires of the past is that powerful people no longer attempt to win the world by conquest, instead choosing to take the world through financial means. It's much easier, cheaper, better for public relations, and easier to hide because the system itself is always there as a scapegoat. Is this really going on right now? Hard to say. Read Modern Money Mechanics and decide for yourself, don't just take my word for it. Learn for yourself. Form your own opinion of the world based on facts and evidence from reputable, scientific sources. Never let someone else do your thinking for you.

 you're assuming that the gas will completely cover the globe through diffusion and still have any biological activity if it did? Assuming there is a biologically active chemical in these chemtrails (I do not believe in this theory) it'd at least be heavy enough to not spread far away. And any biologically active drug cannot stay around forever, so you can't really say it'll be effective after a set traveled distance.

Nowadays, the word true is now synonymous for the words official, certified, or statistically relevant. But if no government, organization approved by government is willing to research these theories and publish the reports, can you really debunk them?

As for the cure for cancer, there is evidence that less-profitable methods are usually discouraged, such as the famous example of peptic ulcer cure. "we" (conspiracy theorists?) know that nobody wants to be unhealthy, but there are many case studies that prove that businessmen talking to the science community sometimes screw humanity over for a few years because they're solitary wolves and not a colony of ants.

Sometimes the conspiracies cover up some other things. Let's say the hole in ozone was a lot worse than they say, the chemtrail thing might be the only band-aid they could think of. Certain metal salts which are potentially bad under long exposure conditions also happen to be the only thing that knocks down UV by 80%. It wouldn't be that they're trying to poison everyone, but trying to cover up a much bigger f'up that had large and seemingly overwhelming environmental consequences.

Other conspiracies would work to hold the existing power structure in place. Stuff like free energy or anti-gravity would potentially make people resource independent of government and related power structures. It's odd but a lot of busy-bodys don't like to mind their own business, and they often find their way into positions of power. Imagine if it was economically feasible to build your own spaceship and leave them behind for good. The busy-body types wouldn't like that.

And of course it's been in the history of humans that since somebody figured out how to use a rock as a tool, that it can also serve as a weapon. And the trend has continued since. Some great new or disruptive technologies may be purposely obfuscated or obstructed in development because of this factor. Something useful for "free" energy like a mass-energy converter just might be able to nuke a city, but without need for hard to obtain and handle materials like current fission weapons.

I appreciate this, but you shoulda spent more time and effort on the video. All of these crackpot theories about chemtrails, global warming, water fluoridation, and so on are getting in the way of having an actual discussion about real, concerning issues. "Conspiracy Theories" have become such a polarizing subject that NOBODY will set aside their discomfort with the matter to get to the bottom of it. Conspiracy Theories range from the outright ridiculous to the superficially compelling. Some are elaborate hoaxes, and others are obviously just satirical. The ones people are most concerned with have some fractional value of truth to it. There's bound to be a level of baseless speculation and intellectual dishonesty mixed into them, but the important question is why they attract so many people. I see this a lot, and no matter how intellectual or scientific, people will simply assume some personal element about their world view, or construct a terrifying image of toxic stupidity to collectively alienate them. There is no effort to understand anything here. In fact, just bringing up the lapse in understanding makes people uncomfortable. Here's my take. Most people will buy into something that sounds good. They'll eventually realize it was stupid and move on. Some people, however, develop an ideology that's validated by some aspect of the conspiracy theories. This ideology gives the person emotional and moral support, and if you've heard of the YouTuber Sargon of Akkad, he recently made a video named The Ideological Lens explaining this phenomena. I think this is part of it. At least a significant part of the conspiracy theory culture. What people refuse to consider is that the shear volume of conspiracy theorist drivel is drowning out whatever legitimate facts or concerns lay just outside of them. People will build a mental wall whenever they hear a certain meme, and they paint everything on the other side of that wall with the same brush. The vice here is in a lack of discussion. So, at the end of the day, "Conspiracy Theory" was a term developed by the CIA to obscure and desaturate the discussion of controversial subjects.

I love almost ALL of your videos but this one?  Well, your logic is what is referred to as a 'hasty generalization.'  Take Chem Trails for example.  There is abundant proof that there has been a significant uptick in cloud dispersal missions by various countries, and the general consensus is an attempt to reduce Global Climate Change, which is a very serious problem.  Is there proof?  A little, though it is obscure.  Does that mean that Chem Trails are not real?  No.  So, it is best to do more research before dismissing the concept or conspiracy theory or hypothesis, etc.  Many conspiracy theories or conjectures or suggestions are often conflated with idiocy and neurotic or paranoid people.  But time and time again, history has proven many conspiracies to be in fact, leaks about very real events that only become historical fact much later.  It is worth investigating conspiracies for many reasons, but just that alone ought to be reason enough.

I'll preface this with the statement that I do not believe in any of those more fantastic/dramatic conspiracy theories that tend to fly around.

I disagree with the nature of this "simple" debunking question. By asserting that all conspiracies that are or can be related to the powerful or the rich are automatically not true purely on the basis that it includes the powerful or the rich, it's effectively shutting out discussion or resolution of a given idea without seeking proof.

Does this work in a couple cases? Of course. If you ignore enough of the wide variety that conspiracy theories can come in and select only the ones that your question works with, then it will most certainly seem valid. But, let's try this one out:

Conspiracy theory: The rich in the United States are manipulating their government to provide themselves with greater loopholes in tax code, and prolong correction of these issues.

Proof: The general sales tax has spiked from nothing in 1920 to 13.5% on all goods in some locations. It is now deemed acceptable to tax infrastructure maintenance through the construction of toll roads. Certain sections of the police force are graded on performance by the number of tickets they hand out on a daily/weekly basis. Thees are all examples of taxation after the government has already taken its designated share of an individual's paycheck, and each more severely affects the middle class/poor than it does those with a larger disposable income. The reason the government has been doing this is because over the last ~50 years, the richest 1% (those that have a household income of 500,000 annually or higher) have reduced their effective tax rate from 60% to nearly ~20%, if loopholes such as "tax credits" are factored into their funds.

According to this video, since it involves the rich, it is false. I understand that the rich and powerful are popular targets for conspiracy theories, but there's a reason for that. The average and the poor don't exactly have the economic power necessary to orchestrate what many of these theories claim. However, instead of making foolish assumptions like this video encourages, why not teach people about Occam's Razor and its potential applications to theories, since it was designed for theoretical discussion in the first place?

You can't completely debunk this conspiracy by asking, "does it affect rich/powerful people?"

Yeah Steve Jobs died of cancer, but whether or not he had access to "the cure," it would still be withheld to avoid destroying the profits of the pharmaceutical and health care industries.

So he gets the secret cure and continues to live. Okay, the cure must be pretty pricey. Charge the rich a percentage of their net worth (considering they want to live with significantly less money), but keep it from the general public so profits can be made from less expensive, but more available treatment.

My point is that you can leverage the exclusive cure for cancer, and the more widely available treatment for cancer to make consumers pay the most money. If you make the cure for cancer available you have to set it at a price that will appeal to the general population. If it's too expensive (at the rich/powerful price) not enough people will buy it. If you keep the ongoing treatment for cancer and the exclusive cure, the general population will continue to invest money into the hope of living and fighting cancer, while the rich/powerful haggle a hefty price.

I don't believe in the conspiracy. I'm just saying the argument isn't sound.

My own thought:
The human brain is, by its nature, always looking for structures in the information it gathers. Now, with all the bits of information around, it can easily conclude to recognise a reason or a mastermind behind all the structure it created from the information.

That conclusion might be right, but it does not have to be right.

I got this idea from this:
I recently loaded a computer game and a save game from like three years ago. It is a game of establishing and managing transport routes. There were MANY things going on on my screen and it looked like chaos. It took me one hour of hard concentration to seep through all the transport lines and to understand them again. Thing is: all lines of transport were simple point-to-point connections. Very simple when regarded individually, but very confusing when seeing everything in action at the same time.

Since then I stick to a very simple rule: the simpler theory might be more likely. And conspiration is NOT simple in practice.

The typically given counterargument is that the rich and powerful "must not be the real rich and powerful people", and that "behind them" are the "real" powerful that we don't know about. This argument also has some issues; those others "behind" them presumably also do things like breath air or get cancer. To that they usually invoke supernatural things. And so they will just inflate their conspiracy theory willy-nilly without thinking of how this diminishes the probability of their theory being true, like two boys endlessly one-upping each other's imaginary powers.

The real world does have deals and agreements between the powerful, but these deals historically come and go, as do positions of power. To assume that there are some who magically supersede this pattern is very dramatic and cool, but not a very good explanation for what we observe. The old-money rich families are either uncommonly good at asset-preservation and caution by perhaps genes or family culture, or they got very lucky. No need to invoke supernatural foo-foo.

Here's a bit of logic on conspiracies.
1. People can accomplish more, with less difficulty working together, pooling resources, than each individual can separately.
2. Any large project initiative that stands to change anything will inevitably be met with opposition by those who currently have a vested interest in that something not changing - if they know about it. Therefore, the less the general public knows about any given endeavor, the less opposition it will be met with, and, consequently, the easier it will be to accomplish.

3. Therefore, there will inevitably be groups of people working together to further common interests, as secretively as they can manage. And that is the definition of conspiracy.
4. Therefore, the world is rife with conspiracies, inevitably. Simple logical extrapolation from self-evident premises tells us this. We don't need to know any "secret facts."

5. Why anyone should consider "conspiracy theory" to be a derogatory term is beyond me. I can think of no good reason why humans should not theorize about the conspiracies. We theorize about everything else, as well we should. These "theories" are actually more often hypotheses, at least at first, and are the foundations of investigation. And investigation is the foundation of progress, the bedrock of science, without which we have little more than baseless imaginative belief.
6. So, if you come across in your life a set of data that seems like counter-evidence to what you have been told, something that raises the proverbial "red flags" in your mind, try to figure out what's going on. You will be made to feel stupid for doing so, call names like "conspiracy theorist" and "tinfoil hat wearer." But that is because the people doing so ARE stupid. Too stupid to grasp that to question and hypothesize is a virtue, not a vice.

So, here's a 'kurzgesagt' little conspiracy hypothesis for you: It is nearly always in the interest of those who hold power to hinder the disempowered form understanding the nature - the structures and mechanisms - of the power, lest they should seek to take it unto themselves. Therefore, they do what they can to stigmatize efforts to understand the aspects of reality that too closely relate to human power. Economics and politics, for example.
Humans, as social creatures, are very sensitive to ostracism, so the vast majority are eager to adopt the mindset they perceive to be the majority mind-set, whatever it may be, in order to better fit in. They jostle together in groups of self-confirming ideologues, and scoff at the endeavors of the intellectually more courageous. The mediocrity of normalcy is their high ideal.
So, in my opinion, even the proponents of the theories that are flat out mistaken - as many of them are - are(as long as they are earnest) far more intellectually courageous and morally virtuous than the cowards who scoff - bankrupt of any virtue of their own - nudge each other in the ribs, and try to pretend that scoffing makes them superior.

In probabilistic terms, the idea that no conspiracy theory is true is one of the most absurd statements you can make, especially as you learn more about many of the theories on the internet, that support each other and are self-reinforcing.

As a brief example: Does the Bush family have a longstanding relationship with the Saudi Royal family? Yes. If tinfoil-hatters are going to believe a conspiracy theory, they should pick something PLAUSIBLE. There are plenty of examples of WARRANTED conspiracy theories, but my favorite is the Reichstag fire. I'll compare this to a less plausible one, say, faking the moon landing.

First, let's look at the logistics. The Reichstag fire only needed a handful of people and a shoestring budget to pull off. Faking the moon landing would need at least tens of thousands of people, and the costs would be astronomical. NASA and the Feds would go bankrupt trying. The lunar rock samples would take decades to falsify, and filming would need a soundstage orders of magnitude bigger than any known vacuum chamber.

Second, is this the easiest way? If not, why was this chosen over an easier way? Also, WHO BENEFITS AND AT WHAT PRICE? The Nazis had the incentive of scapegoating the German communists and it's hard to imagine an easier way to do it. As for the moon landing, faking it could have given the Feds something to show for NASA's work, but the simpler option was to JUST LAND ON THE GODDAMN MOON! Also, Richard Nixon has been dead for decades, so it's hard to imagine someone currently in power benefiting from fooling Americans into thinking we really landed on the moon once.

Third of all, does belief in this conspiracy theory require the conspirators to be highly intelligent, impeccably competent, well-funded, grossly wasteful, horrifically incompetent, and bone stupid all at the same time? Case in point: Chemtrails. This would need a government that fits all these conditions all at once. High-altitude spraying of chemicals to drug people would have no effect--the concentrations might as well be homeopathic. It also would be the worst-kept secret ever, as the chemicals could easily be detected through air sampling and spectrography.

How many times do humans have to get their face rubbed into how ego-centric, self-centered, short-sighted they are? In group 1, these things may or may not be real, they should not simply be thrown on the sidewalk and called bullshit just because they are labeled "conspiracies". They very well may be true. A lot of what's in this group have some solid evidence.

Group 2, unless some very major evidence is brought forth, stuff in this group can be ignored. Rarely does something in this group turn out to be true. (MKultra, the Tuskegee experiments are 2 conspiracies from this group that came true)

People who believe that stuff in group 1 and 2 may be true, are still considered sane at this point.

Group 3 is crazy batshit zone. Practically nothing from this group has any value, and is pretty much always wrong. People who thing stuff from this group is true, are pretty much crazy.

The biggest trap I've seen when it comes to conspiracy theories is people not understanding that an explanation that is internally consistent with "your chosen conspiracy" is NOT evidence. 
It's not evidence because for any event, you can come up with dozens of different explanations that are perfectly consistent with an outcome and are often unfalsifiable. 

e.g Continental unions are forming because the Illuminati want's a one world government, George Bush is behind 9/11 so he could invade Afghanistan, Water supplies have added substances that keep the population docile so the government can remain in control etc

They are all consistent in an odd way but they are also merely claims, and a claim that is consistent is still a claim none the less and should NEVER be treated as evidence.

The first one with Steve Jobs is actually a really bad example and is quite frankly lazy. Just because a famous rich person dies from cancer doesn't necessarily mean that there aren't potentially viable, yet unorthodox, cancer treatments out there that don't see the light of day due to the difficult nature of powerful pharmaceutical corporations and highly-collusive government personnel (especially within the FDA).

Now I'm all for debunking conspiracy theories that don't have any grounding, but the cancer thing was handled terribly. There are definitely a few treatments out there that are swept under the rug by the actions of pharmaceutical corporations. A really interesting documentary called "Burzynski" surfaced a few years ago which attested to this, as well as various medical marijuana documentaries that touch on this.

While this debunking method is ostensibly solid, it only works for the most inane of conspiracy theories. The short video doesn't take into account the nature of bureaucracy and the role of money, powerful people, and the media in protecting profit. Actual conspiracies do occur in this way. A now famous example (thanks to the documentary 'Cosmos'), was the leaded gasoline industry back in the day. Claire Patterson had strong evidence that leaded gasoline was simply awful for people, but instead of acknowledging this and reworking gasoline for the public good, the gas giants destroyed his reputation, pulled his funding, and fought him tooth and nail to obscure the truth. Again, there are numerous examples of real conspiracies throughout history. Am I saying there's a magic pill locked up somewhere? No, that would be jumping to conclusions. Not smart...

...I'm saying, powerful corporations have the ability and incentive (obviously) to protect their own interest, and this video overlooks this entirely in its oversimplification of the conspiracy debunking process. It takes much more information than a simple "does it affect rich and powerful people?" to put conspiracies to rest. I mean Hitler's own men attempted to assassinate him, JFK's initial death explanation made zero sense, and the U.S. government has been proven to be responsible for the death of MLK. These examples, among many others should tell people how non-credible the "rich and powerful" argument really is. The "rich and powerful" simply can't be viewed as a single cohesive group in this context, because some conspiracies are corporation/agency-specific, and then beyond that, corporations and government agencies have heavy chain of command, as well, and things that are on a need-to-know basis. Ugh...

I have some added rules that disproves all crank conspiracy theories (feel free to add your own!):
>is their not enough, uncontested and reasonable evidence?
>could a scientist easily prove it wrong?
>speaking of, does the majority of the scientific community say otherwise?
>has the evidence not been under review for the past (and i'm being generous) 10 years?
>is the evidence anecdotal in nature?
>does the evidence have multiple conflicting, easily provable and factually supported counterarguments? 
>is the evidence biased? politically, ideologically or otherwise?
if you said yes to 1 or more of these question, it is probably wrong, or seriously flawed

This vídeo is really wrong. It oversimplifies and ridicularizes the whole idea of conspiracy theories by specificly picking the most ridiculous ones. They reduce all the analyses to a single , simple and broad question, and then proceed to use this completly made-up, oversimplified method on some examples, as if doing so was some sort of proof of the accuracy of the method.

I know that in the vídeo he said that it doesn't apply to all theories, but he does really quiclky and not remarking it. It's similar to what the media does, when they show one new which is interesting for them 90% of the time, and the other ones which are against their interest they mearly mention.

Also, I understand that simplifing is within the format of Kurzgesagt's vídeos, but this only works for Science vídeos. In them, you need to teach and explain something to someone, so it's OK, or ever better, to make it simple. In the case of vídeos like this one, they need to convince people and give actual arguments, so they can't just try to simplify it and ignore all the rest of the discussion.

And finally, I know that many may think , by reading, this that I am pro-conspiracy theories, but I'm not. Many of them have flaws and I don't believe in them, but I'm open minded. This vídeos is so generic, it uses such a close-minded way of thinking, that it basicly threats all theories as something for lunatics.

I'm not exactly sure about the "suppressed cure for cancer" one. I think the point of that conspiracy theory is not that "only rich people (i.e. Steve Jobs) get the cure" but that "the cure has not been distributed because it would cripple certain portions of the medicinal industry, losing lots of rich people lots of money" Not so sure about the validity of that conspiracy theory though, because researching takes a lot of money, and whether or not a cure has been found many people are still researching new/better cures for certain types of cancer.

Do I think that there's some sort of panacea for all kinds of cancer (or at least one being suppressed), no. Do I think there are cures for some kinds of cancer that have not been released yet, yes but they're probably still in the research and approval phase. And also there are currently medicines that have been known to alleviate/kill cancer cells of certain types, but they're extremely expensive. Maybe that's the point of the conspiracy theory, that there's some cheap cancer-curing medicine out there. But the pharmaceutical companies would just skyrocket the price of that panacea drug because higher demand allows for higher prices before people stop paying. That is probably what would happen if Hydrogen cars became popular. Because it cripples the gas/oil industry it probably won't become a huge industry, and even if it did we would start getting taxed for water as if it was a fuel.

This looks like one case of an application of Bayes' Theorem.
where
A = the conspiracy is real
 or  the conspiracy is not real
B = rich people act as if there is no conspiracy 
P(A | B) = P(B | A)*P(A)/P(B)
Implies that the probability of there being a conspiracy is very low (pretty much zero), assuming that rich people would act differently if the conspiracy was real.
By changing B to something like "X act(s) a certain different way" for several X's you can get arbitrarily close to certainty; if you can measure/estimate probabilities well and if you account for interfering factors (eg. The person thinks that astrology is a thing that has any impact on real life and is rich because s/he  won the lottery).
Bayes' Theorem is the best. Perhaps my favorite theorem. :)
